factoid: Pétya felt that he no longer looked presentable.
Pétya feared that if he approached the gentlemen-in-waiting in that plight he would not be admitted to the Emperor.
It was impossible for Pétya to smarten himself up or move to another place because of the crowd.
One of the generals who drove past was an acquaintance of the Rostóvs.
Pétya thought of asking that general for help.
Pétya concluded that asking that general would not be a manly thing to do.
When the carriages had all passed in, the crowd carrying Pétya streamed forward into the Krémlin Square.
The Krémlin Square was already full of people.
People were present in the square, on the slopes, and on the roofs.
As soon as Pétya found himself in the square he heard the sound of bells and the joyous voices of the crowd that filled the whole Krémlin.
For a while the crowd was less dense.
Suddenly all heads were bared and everyone rushed forward in one direction.
Pétya was being pressed so that he could scarcely breathe.
Everybody shouted "Hurrah! hurrah! hurrah!".
Pétya stood on tiptoe and pushed and pinched, but could see nothing except the people around him.
All the faces bore the same expression of excitement and enthusiasm.
A tradesman’s wife stood beside Pétya and sobbed.
The tears ran down her cheeks.
She repeated "Father! Angel! Dear one!" and wiped away her tears with her fingers.
"Hurrah!" was heard on all sides.
For a moment the crowd stood still, but then it made another rush forward.
Pétya, beside himself, clinched his teeth and rolled his eyes ferociously, pushed forward, elbowed his way, and shouted "hurrah!".
Pétya was prepared that instant to kill himself and everyone else.
On both sides of Pétya other people with similarly ferocious faces pushed forward and everybody shouted "hurrah!".
Pétya thought "So this is what the Emperor is!".
Pétya thought "No, I can’t petition him myself—that would be too bold.".
Pétya continued to struggle desperately forward.
From between the backs of those in front Pétya caught glimpses of an open space with a strip of red cloth spread out on it.
The crowd swayed back because the police in front were pushing back those who had pressed too close to the procession.
The Emperor was passing from the palace to the Cathedral of the Assumption.
Pétya unexpectedly received a blow on his side and ribs.
Pétya was squeezed so hard that everything grew dim before his eyes and he lost consciousness.

When Pétya came to himself, a man of clerical appearance with a tuft of gray hair at the back of his head and wearing a shabby blue cassock was holding him under the arm with one hand while warding off the pressure of the crowd with the other.
The clerical clerk said "You’ve crushed the young gentleman!".
The clerical clerk said "What are you up to? Gently!... They’ve crushed him, crushed him!".
The Emperor entered the Cathedral of the Assumption.
The crowd spread out again more evenly.
The clerical clerk led Pétya, pale and breathless, to the Tsar-cannon.
Several people were sorry for Pétya.
A crowd turned toward Pétya and pressed round him.
Those who stood nearest Pétya attended to him, unbuttoned his coat, seated him on the raised platform of the cannon, and reproached those others who might be crushed him.
Voices said "One might easily get killed that way! What do they mean by it? Killing people! Poor dear, he’s as white as a sheet!".
Pétya soon came to himself, the color returned to his face, and the pain had passed.
At the cost of that temporary unpleasantness Pétya obtained a place by the cannon from where he hoped to see the Emperor who would be returning that way.
Pétya no longer thought of presenting his petition.
If Pétya could only see the Emperor he would be happy.
